item.title: Tina Shull
item.description: Project Director Tina Shull, PhD, is an Assistant Professor of Post-1960 US History at UNC Charlotte.

item.title: Bo Daraphant
item.description: Art contributor Bo Daraphant, or Bo Thai, is an artivist, social entrepreneur, and an immigrant from Thailand.

item.title: Saumaun Heiat
item.description: Saumaun Heiat is a graduate of the Elliott School of International Affairs at George Washington University.

item.title: Emma Crow-Willard
item.description: Impact Producer Emma Crow-Willard is a filmmaker, scientist, and founder of Roots of Unity Media, formed to combat media stereotypes of women, minorities, and science through film and education.

item.title: Tanaya Dutta Gupta
item.description: Tanaya Dutta Gupta is a doctoral student in the department of Sociology at UC Davis and a visiting researcher at CGIAR FOCUS Climate Security.

item.title: Christine Wheatley
item.description: Christine Wheatley, PhD, is a scholar of global migration, the Executive Director of New-Age Environmental Development of Africa (NED Africa), and a lecturer and consultant with the International Organization for Migration.

item.title: Monica Curca
item.description: Monica Curca is a peacebuilder, artist, and Participatory Action Research facilitator and filmmaker.

item.title: Thor Morales
item.description: Thor Morales is an ethnobiologist, photographer, filmmaker and participatory video & photovoice facilitator in Mexico.

item.title: Sienna Leis
item.description: A self-described ‘climate convert’, Sienna Leis recently finished her Master in Public Administration at the Harvard Kennedy School of Government.

item.title: Hania Marien
item.description: Education consultant Hania Mariën is a doctoral student at the Harvard Graduate School of Education (HGSE).

item.title: Keanu Gorman
item.description: Keanu Gorman is a Diné (Navajo) translator, poet, and researcher. They are an A.

item.title: Who are Climate Refugees?
item.description: The International Organization for Migration (IOM) estimates that in 2019, 25 million people were displaced by climate change-related events.

item.title: Marshall Islands: "Art Stops the Damage"
item.description: Small, low-lying island nations in the South Pacific are some of the most vulnerable locations in the world to the impacts of climate change.

item.title: Bangladesh: "The River Took Everything"
item.description: In 2017-8, Climate Refugee Stories project collaborator Saumaun Heiat worked as a Program Support Officer for the International Organization for Migration in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

item.title: The US-Mexico Border: "Over My Dead Body"
item.description: Climate change not only contributes to conditions globally that drive migration to the United States, but it also exacerbates tensions along the US-Mexico border.

item.title: Central America: "This Caravan is Yours, Mr. Trump"
item.description: When the people of my country of Honduras decide to leave, they do not leave because they lack love for Honduras, but because the need demands it.

item.title: In US Detention: "That Water Had a Strange Smell"
item.description: On any given day, over 50,000 people are held in a network of over 200 federal, local, and privately contracted detention facilities across the country, while over 400,000 people are deported each year.

item.title: Puerto Rico: Stories from Hurricane Maria
item.description: Coming Soon by Emma Crow-Willard & Roots of Unity Media

item.title: Ghana: "I Have Been a Stowaway"
item.description: NED Africa is producing an ethnographic film that captures stories of return migrants to coastal and island communities impacted by rising sea levels along Ghana’s coast.

item.title: Bahamas: "You Should Hear Her Voice"
item.description: In September 2019, Hurricane Dorian became one of the most intense storms to ever hit the Atlantic and the greatest natural disaster to ever make landfall on the islands of The Bahamas.

item.title: The Navajo Nation: Sheep Stories
item.description: Coming Soon by Keanu Gorman

item.title: Guyana: "This Isn't Climate Change"
item.description: Known for its extreme rainy season, the lowlands of Guyana have been significantly impacted by flooding for more than 15 years.
